subject: Re: [junit] Digest Number 778
msgSnippet: ... From: J. B. Rainsberger  ... That is all true - but I didn t say that a dedicated unit tester s purpose was to replace TDD -
messageBody:
----- Original Message -----
From: "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@...>


>
> Hear, hear.
>
> The goal of Programmer Tests is to for the programmer to:
>
> * have tangible evidence of progress
> * clarify the needs of the design
> * "eat his own dog food" by being forced to write client code before
> writing provider code
> * keep focus on small steps
> * avoid writing too much code in one flow
>
> I don't see how a dedicated unit tester can make that happen for a
> programmer.

That is all true - but I didn't say that a dedicated unit tester's purpose
was to replace TDD - what I said was that the dedicated unit tester helped
in getting more and better tests earlier. A dedicated unit tester also helps
introduce the concept and value of unit and early testing to teams,
management, companies and developers. This helps get your foot in the door.
You have to remember that there are a lot of companies out there that don't
practice XP or even halfway decent practices, and you can't make them
swallow XP or TDD all in one gulp. The purpose of any good practice is to
improve the quality of software, but you can't accomplish that in one fell
swoop.

>
> What I *can* see is how a dedicated tester can think of tests that the
> programmer didn't need to drive the design, or just plain missed.
> Still, a dedicated unit tester seems to aim at the wrong spot. A
> dedicated integration tester or end-to-end tester seems about right.
>

Early testing has a value all its own, whether it is accomplished by TDD, or
dedicated unit testers or both. As I said in original post, developers
typically don't have the aptitude, attitude or experience to write good test
cases. TDD is great, but if the quality of the tests the developer writes
suck, then bugs in the design and the code are going to make it through.
That is where a dedicated unit tester shines; they serve as an independent
and fresh unbiased set of eyes on the code/design. If you just assume that
the tests written by developers during TDD were good enough, and then wait
until integration or system testing to test again, you are going to be
surprised by an existing bugs that you could have probably caught earlier.
You will also be risking big-bang integration, or at least one aspect of it.

I have been on both sides of the fence; I have equal years experience in
both QA/Testing and on the development side of the software engineering
fence (15+ years in all), and typically, a developer will not test their own
code as well or as thoroughly as an independent tester - especially a good
tester who has the right attitude.

Development/writing code is essentially a creative process, and a creative
attitude is usually the result. Testing is a destructive process and it
often takes a destructive attitude (and aptitude) to properly test software.
Some developers can do it, but usually not right off the bat - many
developers never truly get the hang of it. TDD is good, but it does not
obviate the need for further testing, and as with all testing, the earlier
it is done, the earlier you will find bugs - and that is a "good thing".

> I feel appropriately inspired. Let me write the article, then I'll be
> back. :)

I don't see the need. As I said I don't see a conflict between TDD and
independent unit testing. The two can coexist. The only danger I would see
with both coexisting is that the developer may adopt the attitude that since
there is an independent unit tester, that there is no reason for him/her to
do TDD. That is a mistake in comprehension, logic and a flawed conclusion -
it requires education, not the elimination of independent unit testing. The
same could be said for any kind of testing right? After all, why do
integration or system testing if we already did TDD? TDD catches all bugs
anyway right? Why bother with further testing? Wrong!

If I had developers that wrote poor tests because they felt the unit testers
would catch the bugs anyway, I would probably approach the situation the
same as if I had a developer who wrote poor code because testers would
sooner or later find any bugs. If they couldn't be made to see the wisdom of
early testing and TDD, then I would probably replace them with someone who
did.

Now maybe some people out there have a unique team of developers who really
do write such good tests during TDD that an independent unit tester would
just be a waste of time. Kewl! Good for you! Then don't waste the time. But
I live in the real world where developers don't write good tests, especially
for their own code. I also live in a world where management and developers
are often resistant to XP practices (hell, even I don't really care for
Paired Programming).

The original question was not about TDD vs. independent unit testing, the
original question was how do you justify either one to management and
project teams. The fact that the question was asked indicates a problem that
I suggested a possible way to get your foot in the door. Unless you are
starting a new company, or a new team, and you are starting a new project,
you often have to find a way to ease these practices in the back door. Most
of us don't have the luxury or ability of starting anew from scratch, and we
have to get management and recalcitrant developers to buy into new ideas.

Also, as I said, don't make the mistake of hubris in thinking that TDD is
going to find all the bugs and that an independent unit tester wouldn't find
at least some also - I dare say that an independent unit tester would
probably find numerous bugs. Hire me and I will prove it to you. ;-)

FWIW,
Lauren
